newsitem.title: LEBANON: Lebanon T-bill auction raises 320.9 bln pounds.
newsitem.headline: Lebanon T-bill auction raises 320.9 bln pounds.

text.p: Lebanon's weekly treasury bill issue of July 31 raised 320.9 billion Lebanese pounds, according to finance ministry results issued on Monday.
The previous issue raised 354.5 billion pounds.
The issue posted a nominal deficit of subscription against maturity of 76.2 billion pounds for the third consecutive week. The July 24 issue had posted a nominal deficit of 33.9 billion pounds.
Banking sources said the results of the August 7 auction, which will be announced next week, would show a shrinking deficit.

"The July 30 issue marked the peak of the deficit crisis. In the results of next auction, we will see a reduction of deficit which will lead to a reversal of the (deficit) trend," a banking source said.
He said the central bank was a net buyer on the foreign exchange market.
The July 31 issue raised the following amounts (in billion of pounds, previous week in brackets):

The central bank said 10 percent of all competitive bids -- those made by Lebanese institutions -- were accepted up to the discount rate and yield for three-month bills and 50 percent for the six-month bills.

It also restricted the acceptance of non-competitive bids -- those made by private individuals and foreign investors -- for the shorter-term bills, approving 10 percent up to the discount rate and yield for three-month bills and 50 percent for six-month bills.
All competitive and non-competitive bids were approved for one-year and two-year bills.
The Lebanese pound closed at 1,537.25 to the U.S. dollar on Monday from 1,537.75 a week earlier and 1,566 a year ago.
